list_definition.definition: to work for a person etc, eg as a servant

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He served his master for forty years.

list_definition.definition: to distribute food etc or supply goods

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She served the soup to the guests
Which shop assistant served you (with these goods)?

list_definition.definition: to be suitable for a purpose

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: This upturned bucket will serve as a seat.

list_definition.definition: to perform duties, eg as a member of the armed forces

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He served (his country) as a soldier for twenty years
I served on the committee for five years.
He served (a sentence of) six years for armed robbery.

list_definition.definition: in tennis and similar games, to start the play by throwing up the ball etc and hitting it

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He served the ball into the net
Is it your turn to serve?

list_ex_of_english: The food is typically served only after any business, such as praying, is complete, and only then is there much conversation.
It is not clear how dynamical systems serve as a psychological explanation as opposed to a complex description of behavior.
The notion of "change over time" in dream content (from ancestral themes to current themes) is problematic because such change would serve no obvious function.
The possibility remains, however, that the pamphlet was not used in performance but served a purely symbolic purpose.
The teachers, as working women who were active in civic affairs, served as role models to the pupils.
In fact, the controlled laboratory events that served as the mnemonic targets of this investigation were relatively pedestrian.
Future work may serve to consolidate some of the findings from this useful review.
Our paper served to report about specific systems, a composition, and a performance.
